Python and R

  • Both are ommonly used in Academia
  • Both are “Open Source”
  • Python is newer than R but increasingly used as an entry language in academic work
  • R was created with statisticians in mind and is really great at this use case
  • Both are beginner friendly in different ways with different learning curves
Python is generally considered beginner friendly because it uses clear naming but R has RStudio which can be really helpful for beginners. Similarly some think that Python has a long even learning curve but that R starts off with an easy curve that escalates really quickly if you want to do more challenging things.

Questions to consider are:

  • Is my discipline using one more than the other?
  • How much time do I have to upskill?
  • What support exists for you on campus
  • What do you enjoy working with the most?
  • What are you trying to achieve?
  • Who are you communicating to?
  • What types of visualizations are appropriate to your data and which libraries / packages / frameworks hit your goals.
  • What kind of an output do you need? Level of interactivity?

Reproducibility is always important but particularly so in the academic context.

Great talk from PyData in 2017 --

  • Is it a presentation?
  • Is it a static interactive file / site?
  • Is it a full web app?
  • Static website or document
  • Computational Notebook
  • Web applications with a server

What is a dashboard?

  • A collection of visualizations that can interact with each other.
  • Regardless of tool there are some common structural elements.
    • Front-end visuals users interact with
    • Data that informs the visuals
    • In other words: inputs and outputs
